Expectation1: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation1: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I sit hunched over my laptop, the cursor blinking accusingly at the half-finished results section. The journal’s submission portal is open in another tab, the countdown to the deadline ticking away. As a scientist, I know I must double-check every figure, ensure the data is clean, and the conclusions are honest. My reputation—and the integrity of the work—depend on it. But my phone buzzes with a reminder: today is voting day. I promised myself I’d go early, but I realize my ID is in my other bag, at home. I could fetch it later, but what if the lines are long, or I get caught up in revisions? The expectation to participate as a responsible citizen weighs on me, but so does the duty to report my research truthfully and on time. My mind races, torn between the lab and the polling station, between the demands of science and democracy. I stare at the screen, heart pounding, knowing I can’t do both perfectly, and feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
